text:
Wildfires have devastated the 
historic town of Lahaina and
claimed the lives of at least 55 people in Maui.

And driverless taxis have been given the 
green light to operate in San Francisco.

Good morning. I'm Windsor Johnston, with 
NPR News, and here are today's top stories:

Fast-moving wildfires continue to 
rage across Maui, leaving widespread

destruction in their path. The blazes have 
decimated the historic town of Lahaina,

a popular destination for tourists. Tiffany 
Kidder Winn owns a business there. She says

she returned to the community yesterday 
to get a first-hand look at the damage:

"As I walked, though, it started getting worse 
— power lines down and then started to see

smoke and, I mean, there was smoke everywhere, 
but it was getting thicker, and cars burned,

and apartment complexes burned. And 
the further we got onto Front Street,

the more devastating it was 
— just everything leveled."

Authorities say the wildfire that engulfed 
Lahaina is now 80% contained. At least 55

people have died in the fires, with 
the death toll expected to rise.

Attorneys for former President Donald 
Trump will be in court today in Washington,

D.C. NPR's Kristin Wright reports prosecutors in 
the 2020 election conspiracy case are asking a

judge for a protective order that would seek to 
prevent Trump from improperly sharing evidence:

"Special Counsel Jack Smith's team is legally 
required to disclose evidence in the case to

former President Trump and his defense team. 
Prosecutors are concerned Trump will reveal

sensitive information and target witnesses, 
compromising the trial. Prosecutors requested

a protective order last Friday, hours after 
the former president posted on his Truth Social

platform, "If you go after me, I'm coming after 
you." Trump defends his comments, made the day

after his arraignment, saying a protective 
order would violate his free speech. Today,

a judge is hearing arguments from both sides. 
Last week, Trump pleaded not guilty to conspiring

to overturn the results of the 2020 election 
and block the peaceful transition of power.
"Kristin Wright, NPR News."
A utilities commission in California has voted to

allow driverless car companies to 
act like taxis in San Francisco,

but as NPR's Dara Kerr reports, they're 
facing resistance from emergency responders:

"The San Francisco police and fire 
departments have been vocal about

their opposition to driverless cars. 
They say the vehicles have impeded

first responders' operations, running 
through yellow emergency tape and

blocking firehouse driveways. Here's San 
Francisco Fire Chief Jeanine Nicholson:

'Our folks cannot be paying 
attention to an autonomous
vehicle when we've got ladders to throw.'

"Nicholson has been urging California's 
transportation regulator to halt the growth

of driverless vehicle programs 
in the city, but in a 3-1 vote,

regulators decided to allow the programs 
to expand. Now, autonomous vehicles run by

Cruise and Waymo can pick up passengers 
and charge a fare, just like a taxi.
"Dara Kerr, NPR News."

The 2023 Atlantic hurricane season will 
likely be more active than first predicted.

That's according to the National Oceanic 
and Atmospheric Administration. NPR's Jeff

Brady reports NOAA says warmer waters in the 
Atlantic could fuel up to 21 storms this year:

"At the start of the summer, NOAA predicted 
a near-normal number of named hurricanes and

tropical storms this year in the Atlantic. 
Now, the agency projects an above-normal

level of activity. Matthew Rosencrans, with 
NOAA, says warmer water is the main reason:

'The June-July sea surface temperature in 
the main development region of the North

Atlantic were the warmest since 1950, at 
1.23 degrees Centigrade above normal.'

"There's a global trend of rising ocean 
temperatures due, at least in part,

to climate change, though scientists 
are still trying to understand what's
driving the current record-breaking ocean heat.
"Jeff Brady, NPR News."
This is NPR News, in Washington.
